Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type I: Modeling Quantum Tunnel Current to Statistically Sequence Biomolecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
This paradigm shifting project advances the ability to read DNA and proteins and builds on designing nanotechnology systems using machine learning. The goal is to use computational thinking for changing the way biomolecules are designed by providing a synergistic combination of physical modeling, computational data, and adapted statistical learning methods that proactively account for the randomness. Currently all-electronic sequencing of DNA and proteins is a speculative dream that could revolutionize biochemical sciences and medicine. This project investigates theoretically and algorithmically the fundamentals of all-electronic sequencing using a computational framework. Currently, the field of machine learning treats the extraction of useful features from data as largely independent from the design of learning algorithms that act on the extracted features. This project aims at discovering whether significant performance gains can be obtained by designing learning algorithms that explicitly account for the physical variations and randomness in electronic sequencing. The underlying computational thinking can potentially lead to insights and methods leading to transformative advances on all-electronic sequencing of biomolecules.

The research direction of this project can impact biology, medicine, nanoelectronics, and the design of machine learning systems. The training of high school, undergraduate and graduate students in quantum devices and statistical theory and methods in the design and understanding of nanoscale and machine learning systems are an integral part of the activities spanned by this project.

This award is part of the Cyber-Enabled Discovery and Innovation program, and the recipients are Professors M. P. Anantram and Maya Gupta of the University of Washington.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All-electrical sequencing of DNA and disease detection could revolutionize biochemical sciences and medicine. These methods are promising because they have the potential to be inexpensive, faster and portable. Experiments and preliminary technology development to realize this are underway with real data becoming available. Methods to model and interpret data, and predict experimental behavior of electrical conductance in biomolecules is an essential but challenging problem, which requires significant advances. The difference between experiments and models can be many orders of magnitude. In this project, we have taken steps to bridge this gap by developing engineering oriented computational models to study and predict the flow of electrons in DNA molecules connected to two metal contacts. These models have been used to analyze data from experiments probing: electrical methods to detect diseases / electrical barriers for molecular electronics / dependence of electrical conduction on the environment of DNA. During the project period our models have shown that we can qualitatively model the experimental data within an order of magnitude, which opens up the possibility in future to predict the sequence dependent two-terminal resistance in these important biological molecules. We hope that the insights gathered provides a computational way of thinking to study DNA based electronics, and all electrical method for sequencing and disease detection.

The broader impact of the research performed covers medicine, nanoelectronics, and machine learning. The grant supported the doctoral thesis work of two graduate students, one in device modeling and the second in machine learning. One of these graduate students was a female who was the first in family to attend college, and has joined a startup company in a Big Data position after her PhD.  This project also provided challenging scientific problems for the training of an undergraduate and high school intern.

 The publications from this work are:

J. M. Artés, Y. Li, J. Qi, M. P. Anantram, J. Hihath (2015). Conformational Gating of DNA Conductance. Nature Communications 6:8870, DOI: 10.1038/ncomms9870

Jianqing Qi, Niranjan Govind, M. P. Anantram (2015). The Role of Cytosine Methylation on Charge Transport through a DNA Strand.  J. Chem. Phys. 143 (9), 094306. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4929909

J Qi, N Edirisinghe, MG Rabbani, M. P. Anantram (2013). Unified model for conductance through DNA with the Landauer-Büttiker formalism.  Physical Review B. 87 (8), 085404. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.87.085404

Yunqi zhao; Ulrich Hetmaniuk; Sunil Patil; Jianqing Qi; M. P. Anantram (2015). Nested Dissection Solver for Transport in 3D Nano-Electronic Devices.  Submited to Journal of Computational Electronics.

Jianqing Qi and M. P. Anantram (2014). Charge Transport through Methylated DNA Strand. 2014 MRS Spring Meeting, MRS Proceedings, 1689, mrss14-1689-z04-08. DOI:10.1557/opl.2014.595.

Jianqing Qi and M. P. Anantram (2014). Electron Flow in GC8 DNA strand. 2014 ECS and SMEQ Joint International Meeting Published in ECS Transactions, ECS Trans. 2014 volume 64, issue 12, p. 1-9. DOI: 10.1149/06412.0001ecst

M. P. Anantram, Jianqing Qi (2013). Modeling of electron transport in biomolecules: Application to DNA. 2013 IEEE International Electron Devices Meeting (IEDM), Pages 32.3.1 - 32.3.4. DOI: 10.1109/IEDM.2013.6724736

Arora, Raman ; Gupta, Maya R. ; Kapila, Amol ; Fazel, Maryam (2013), Similarity-based clustering by left-stochastic matrix factorization, Journal of Machine Learning Research, Vol.14, pp.1715-1746

Feldman, Sergey ; Gupta, Maya R. ; Frigyik, Bela A. (2012), Multi-task averaging, Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 2012, Vol.2, pp.1169-1177

Arora, Raman ; Gupta, Maya R. ; Kapila, Amol...
